The goal is to have housing production and financing carried out by private sector developers and financial institutions. Lower-income households will benefit from all project components. Project Description: The proposed project has three components: a) Institutional and Policy Development support through a program of institutional capacity building to install and facilitate the development of appropriate policies and institutional mechanisms for the housing sector; b) Housing Finance, to establish the Secondary Mortgage Facility (SMF), initially as a conduit for donor funds to commercial banks making mortgage loans, to be developed at an early date as a market-
 ii driven intermediary, inter alia, through the recruitment of private investors (IFC could become a shareholder when this transition is complete) and a technical partnership with an existing similar institution; a Mortgage Indemnity Fund (MIF); and a transparent and well-targeted Housing Assistance Fund (HAF) to provide direct assistance to lower-income buyers; and c) Housing Development, by introducing procedures and construction finance, starting with a demonstration site, to encourage private developers to produce lower-cost housing units. Benefits and Risks: The main benefit of the proposed project will be to put in place an institutional and policy framework for the housing sector. During the initial phase of the housing finance component, household borrowers will benefit directly through the ability to access mortgage credit to purchase housing. Lenders will benefit by the provision of long-term loans and through a reduction in their liquidity risk. An increased flow of funds to housing may increase employment in construction. Suppliers will also benefit from increased certainty of demand. Although donor funds are the only resources available to the SMF at the outset, technical work on both the SMF and the regulatory environment for long-term savings during the project are anticipated to lead to a subsequent conversion of the SMF to a full market- driven refinance intermediary. Efforts are already underway to seek investors for the SMF and to establish a technical partnership with a successful similar institution in another country. The project seeks to introduce policies and mechanisms which will encourage a responsive flow of private resources to the housing sector and the production of more, lower-cost dwellings. The risks associated with a strategy based on voluntary participation by private entities are substantial. They are: (a) those risks associated with developing and implementing sound public sector policies and institutions, (b) the financial and business risks inherent in the highly uncertain economy of the WBG, and (c) the technical and institutional risks associated with project specific options. Public policy and institutional development is necessarily the core of a project whose objective is longer-term sustainable development of the sector. The particular risk is that the consensus building and decision- making required for successful implementation will take longer than expected. The robustness of the project concept based on experience in many countries and the lack of credible alternatives make this risk worth taking. Similarly, the banks and developers may from time to time be reluctant to play the expected role in the time-frame forecast. Anticipating changing circumstances, the project has been designed with the flexibility to adjust the incentives to private business. The technical and institutional risks of the project design are largely related to unknown reaction of the market to the proposed solutions. Again, the incremental nature of project outputs allows for adjustment and mitigation of this risk.
 iii Poverty Category: The project is not a part of a core poverty program but will support Palestinian efforts to alleviate poverty by creating lower-skilled jobs in urban areas where poverty is most widespread. Moreover, improvements to infrastructure networks and services will also have a positive impact on surrounding neighborhoods and city-wide reduction of health-problems associated with poor sanitation services, which most often affect the poor. Economic Rate of Return: Although it is not possible to estimate an IRR for this project, the initiation of mortgage lending potentially creates substantial benefits. For lenders, the SMF offers an opportunity to reduce the liquidity risk of mortgage lending. For household borrowers, the availability of mortgage loans creates a benefit equal to the substitution of lower cost debt for equity. For those without adequate equity, it provides access to higher quality housing sooner. Broader significant external benefits may be generated by the SMF as an increase in the demand for housing spurred by mortgage lending, stimulates the economy more widely.  WEST BANK AND GAZA HOUSING PROJECT STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT 1. SECTOR BACKGROUND 1.1 With the signing of the Cairo agreement in April 1994, Gaza became relatively autonomous. As a result of signing the Interim Agreement on September 28, 1995, similar autonomy has now been extended to parts of the West Bank. These agreements open up new opportunities for Palestinian development, but they also pose new challenges. Among the more important of the opportunities is the chance to begin systematically addressing critical economic, social, institutional and infrastructure problems. The challenge is to do so efficiently and equitably, and in a manner which best promotes long- term economic and social development objectives. 1.2 The Economy. Using a "poverty line" of annual earnings of US$650 per capita, about half a million people (one-fifth of the population) live in absolute poverty, on less than US$2 per day. This includes approximately 40% of Gazans. Despite some recent easing the Palestinian economy is currently under severe pressure. During the last months of 1995 and into early 1996, the economic situation had begun to improve. A mini-boom in construction was in progress, particularly in Gaza. However, the closure imposed on Gaza and West Bank beginning February 25, 1996, following a series of bombings in Israel, has changed this picture dramatically. The IMF's latest projections' suggest a decline of GDP and GNP of 4.6 and 6 percent respectively for 1996 as a whole, which translates into a loss of per capita magnitude of about 7 and 10 percent respectively. A fiscal deficit of US$127 million is forecast (compared with US$108 million for 1995). This scenario is based on two main assumptions: that restrictions on merchandise trade with Israel will not be a factor in the latter part of the year, and that an average of 25,000 workers in Israel will be employed in Israel from July 1 through December 1996 (currently 32,000 permits have been issued by Israeli authorities though actual employment still falls short of this). 1.3 Employment. According to surveys conducted in October 1996, unemployment stood at 21% with a further 12% of the workforce severely under-employed. These figures represent a modest improvement from data collected six months earlier but unemployment is still very high. About 55,000 permits have been issued for Palestinians to work in Israel as of January 1997 although Palestinians estimates suggest that due to the presence of guest workers in Israel, only about 45,000 Palestinians are currently finding employment. 1.4 Demography. The West Bank and Gaza (WBG) comprises some 6,000 sq. km with a population estimated at 2.5 million in 1994. This population has been growing at a rate of about 4 percent per annum. The West Bank and Gaza differ in demographics, infrastructure and economic status. About 65 percent of the WBG population resides in the West Bank. More than 50 percent of the combined populations are 15 years old or younger. High birth rates, relatively low mortality rates and changing migration patterns are contributing to the rapid rise in population in both areas. 1.5 The West Bank population is widely dispersed among 422 small towns and villages. The West Bank has only six larger urban centers and a population density of 267 persons per square kilometer. The Gaza Strip, by contrast, has a density of 2,225 persons per square kilometer, with 16 larger cities (municipalities) and towns, and only a few small villages. Registered refugees represent 32 "Report on Fiscal Developments during the first half of 1996 and revised macroeconomics and fiscal projections for the second half of 1996", IMFIPA, June 1996.
 2 percent of the West Bank population, of which only one-quarter live in refugee camps. In Gaza, 72 percent of the population are registered refugees, of which about 55 percent live in camps. GNP per capita is significantly lower in Gaza than in the West Bank. Gaza was previously administered by Egypt, while the West Bank was an integral part of Jordan. As a result there are differences in legal regimes, land tenure and transfer procedures, service provision, and even housing types and preferences. 1.6 The Housing Sector. In the past twenty-five years the construction of new housing has been severely constrained both by formal restrictions on land and housing development and by low and uncertain incomes. Strong restrictions were imposed on the transfer of funds into WBG and on the establishment and development of local banking and credit institutions. Housing construction during occupation did not keep pace with needs. Even those with resources faced administrative and legal difficulties in buying or building better housing. 1.7 As a result, Palestinian housing, particularly in the Gaza strip, is characterized by high occupancy densities, poorly functioning land markets and deficient infrastructure. It is estimated that around one-third of all Palestinian households live in situations where there are more than 3 persons per room, and that almost 10 percent live with more than 5 persons per room. About one-quarter of all households have no running water, one fifth have no electricity and over one third have no sanitation facilities. Unlike other countries with housing shortages or populations unable to afford housing, Palestinian families do not usually opt for informal housing such as squatting on public land, renting in slums, etc. Rather, the norm is to expand nuclear households, creating highly crowded conditions. Another problem is the lack of investment in infrastructure and services such as schools, transport, and maintenance to serve existing communities and areas of cities which are expanding with new house construction. 1.8 Until the start of the peace process, the political, economic and institutional constraints affecting the West Bank and Gaza precluded formulating a housing policy or strategy. Palestinian authority over key aspects of the housing sector, such as land markets, regulation, finance, etc. did not exist. Palestinian institutions responsible for the planning, implementation and management of the housing sector are newly established. Their capacities are limited and their policies, regulations, norms and processes are nascent. The Ministry of Housing, established in 1994, has identified the priorities and elements of a housing strategy and policy which are communicated to the Bank in a letter of policy development attached as Annex 1. However, much needs to be done to put the institutions, policies and financing in place so that the housing sector can begin to operate and make progress. 1.9 Since the signing of the Declaration of Principles in 1993 there has been somewhat of a boom in residential construction, especially in Gaza. Although precise data are not available, the total value of new residential construction may be as high as 13.4% of GDP in recent years2 and the total number of new units built in Gaza may be as high as 2,000 per year in 1994 and 1995. This represents a considerable increase over previous periods and reflects in part the uncertainty concerning other investments and business opportunities. The characteristic of much of the new housing is cash-financed, multi-family structures often built in anticipation of demand from returning Palestinians. As a result new units are typically large with high standards and selling prices from US$40,000 to over US$100,000. Most observers of the real estate industry believe this phenomenon to have run its course and that broader stable demand with term financing will be necessary for a healthy housing industry. 2/ Source: Stephen K. Mayo, Housing Sector Perfor-mance and Housing Strategy in Gaza and the West Bank, IBRD, June 1995 unpublished report.
 3 A. Housing Sector Issues and Strategy 1.10 The main housing sector issues fall into four categories: a. the role and structure of the public sector in policy formulation and implementation; b. the high price of housing; the absence of a well-functioning land market; and the limited housing choices available to lower-income households; c. the absence of forrmal financing for the construction or purchase of housing; and d. the need for mechanisms to assist the poor to improve their access to housing. 1.11 Although the need for more and lower cost housing is large and obvious in the West Bank and Gaza, there is considerable uncertainty as to how and when that will be translated into effective demand. The major unknowns are the number and timing of returnees, the disposition of those now living in refugee camps and the general stabilization and growth in incomes for all Palestinians. Although internal migration may not be a significant factor in the housing market given the small geographical area and many established settlements, the demographic pressures both from high birth rates and delayed family formation will continue to stress the housing sector. The deteriorated conditions of many units may also lead to considerable repair and expansion of existing units as is already visible in many areas of the WBG. 1.12 Given the widely varied estimates of the demand for housing, the strategy must necessarily concentrate on creating strong and flexible public and private institutions rather than on planning for a specific output target. In particular, the capacity to finance the sector must be augmented. A well- functioning housing sector will require, in addition to the creation of new institutions, an intensive upgrading of the administrative, managerial and technical capabilities of the local authorities in order to increase their capacity to plan, implement and administer infrastructure extensions and improvements. 1.13 World Bank Strategy. Since 1993, the Bank Group has been actively involved in a broad- based donor effort to assist the WBG. Apart from lending $150 million for 7 projects to date from IBRD profits and net income through the TFGWB, the World Bank has received well over $500 million in cofinancing pledges or trust fund commitments from other donors. The World Bank's strategy for WBG as outlined in the Board paper "Replenishing the Trust Fund for the West Bank and Gaza'" (R96-25 1) focuses on three priority areas: (a) restoring and further developing basic and social infrastructUre: (b) building policy-making and institutional capabilities; and (c) supporting the emergence of the private sector. This project is consistent with these strategic objectives. 1.14 The past year has demonstrated the need for a flexible strategy so that if events require it, the Bank can expand the emergency components of its program. However, the primary goal remains the establishment of a basis for sustained growth in the medium term. In line with the above strategy objectives, the current fiscal year's program and the pipeline of projects for future years focuses on developing infrastructure, capacity building and private sector development. In addition to the efforts already made to-date by the Bank to provide for an enabling environment for private sector development, a significant portion of the US$90 million replenishment of the TFGWB approved in February of this year by the Board of Governors will fund initiatives to further promote the environment necessary for private sector development and developing basic physical and social infrastructure in WBG. 1.15 The Palestinian Authority's Public Investment Programs (PIP)3 which included about US$780 million in physical infrastructure for the 1995-98 period reaffirmed the centrality of basic 31 West Bank and Gaza: Outlook For Public Investment and Associated Funding Needs, July 25, 1995.
 4 physical and social infrastructure rehabilitation, but pointed to the urgent need to rationalize service delivery; establish the policy and institutional arrangements for greater private sector participation; and reduce dependence on external funds to finance recurrent costs.4 The Bank supported this program with a set of five key infrastructure projects: Municipal Infrastructure Development (FY96); Water and Sanitation Services (FY97, focused on Gaza only); Housing Project (FY97-this project); Industrial Estates (FY98); and Electricity Sector Investment and Management (FY98). The first two of these projects are already under implementation; together with a second Emergency Rehabilitation Project (ERP II), they have been funded through a US$90 million replenishment of the TFGWB in 1995. A second US$90 million replenishment was approved by the Governors in February 1997, and the Housing Project will be financed out of these proceeds. 1.16 The severity of the economic crisis which began in late February 1996 also required an immediate emergency response. This was necessary to relieve unemployment, minimize social hardship, and avoid permanent damage to the peace process. In response to the crisis, an emergency employment generation program was developed which created some 15,000 to 20,000-full-time equivalentjobs. This program has been financed through the Holst Fund and more recently by ERP II. 1.17 The Bank has had a continuing relationship with the authorities on housing sector issues. The study, Developing the Occupied Territories: An Investment in Peace, includes a chapter on housing. Bank staff and consultants have led the substantive work on these issues funded by the Technical Assistance Trust Fund (TATF). The assistance provided on housing finance issues directly underpins the present proposals and the policy development work provided the enabling framework adopted by the MOH. This leadership and experience should be an advantage in mobilizing donor financing for this project and for the housing sector. The proposed project is central to situating and linking housing sector policy to key aspects of economic management. The role of the public sector must be consistent with the fiscal realities for the economy. The development of a competitive market-based housing finance system can strengthen and accelerate the development of the financial sector rather than introduce unmanageable risk as often occurs. Bank leadership on housing issues can facilitate these objectives. 2. PROJECT OBJECTIVES AND DESCRIPTION 2.1 Sector and Project Strategy. The present cash-financed production of new housing targeted to wealthy returning Palestinians is not a good long-term basis for a stable and healthy housing sector. A sustainable level of investment with less volatility will materialize if the considerable existing capacity and vigorous output of the private sector is able to shift some production to the construction of lower- cost products and if households wanting to purchase are able to obtain long-term financing. Since increasing the purchasing power of low- and moderate-income households is essential to stimulating the private production of lower-cost housing, some carefully considered incentives are necessary to start this process. The initial phase of the housing finance initiative provides the mechanisms and incentives for formal financing to begin to flow to the housing sector. 2.2 In order to define and launch a Palestinian housing policy, the proposed project seeks to demonstrate that appropriate, lower-cost housing options can be achieved and that financing can be made available on a sustainable basis. The PA has made known its policy toward housing in a number of official documents including a recent communication from the Minister on sector policy and a previous letter to the Bank concerning financing issues, both available in Annex I and other documents listed in Annex 15. At the same time this project initiates a process of policy development and institutional strengthening which is urgently needed to sustain the housing sector in the longer-term. The target beneficiaries for new housing construction and support under this project are the households who can reasonably be expected to save for downpayments and make payments on mortgage loans. This group can also include some households whose income is somewhat below that level that are provided with appropriate but modest assistance. The housing conditions of even lower-income families will be improved through a program of upgrading infrastructure in lower-income neighborhoods supported under the Municipal Infrastructure Development Project, FY96 (Project No. 43339, Report No. 15400- WBGZ). 2.3 The PA requested that the World Bank Group, donors and commercial banks finance 10,000 dwelling units. However, the financial requirements and implementation capacity are currently not available. Therefore, the PA and the Bank have agreed to proceed with a Housing Project funded, in part, by the Bank that over a four-year period will put in place a sustainable system to produce lower- cost housing. To do so the proposed Project is phased to a) establish the institutional and policy environment for the sector, b) install and build the financial mechanisms for starting mortgage lending by commercial banks and assistance for lower-income households, and c) develop an initial Demonstration Site of 1,000 housing units, with a goal of developing an additional 3,000 dwelling units. 2.4 In the absence of established policies, norms, financial instruments, and institutions, the proposed project provides donors, local institutions, and private developers a strategic framework for: a) a quick response to the needs of lower-income households; and b) installing the foundations for building and guiding the housing sector. The physical investment components aim at quickly producing needed housing and supporting urban infrastructure, while demonstrating that the production of appropriate standard, lower-cost housing by private developers is viable. The financing initiative provides the mechanisms and incentives for formal financing to begin to flow to the housing sector. The MOH will be the coordinating and executing agency for the project, with implementation largely in the hands of private sector developers, financial institutions and local authorities. A. Project Objectives 2.5 The project helps launch and support a long-term strategy and program of financial, investment, institutional and policy development. These actions are intended to remove specific bottlenecks in the housing sector in order to improve the functioning of the housing market, particularly for lower- to moderate-income households. A fundamental goal of the project is to put into place a financial system for mortgage lending through the existing commercial banks. Complementary actions include encouraging land development and construction of new lower-cost housing by private developers, providing infrastructure related to the development of new housing, and strengthening sector policies and institutions. 2.6 The project improves access to shelter for lower-income groups by encouraging the construction and acquisition of appropriately designed plots of land, basic dwelling units and apartments based on the response of private supply to effective market demand. A structured schedule of policy formulation and institutional capacity building will help establish a firmer institutional base and provide the much needed regulatory and enabling environment for the effective evolution of the housing sector. 2.7 Because the project is to support the PA's first steps towards the development of the housing sector (including policies, programs, financing, production, and markets), the specific objectives of the project are to: a. put in place institutions, policies and actions necessary to build and sustain a well- functioning housing sector;
 6 b. make housing more affordable by initiating the development of a competitive, market- based mortgage system, accompanied by well-targeted assistance to lower-income households; c. reduce house prices for lower-income households by (i) reducing obstacles to the availability of land; (ii) promoting a competitive development process for lower-cost alternatives; and (iii) providing assistance for the capital costs of infrastructure. B. Project Components 2.8 The three project components are presented below and detailed in Annexes 4 to 8: A. Institutional and Policy Development Component to facilitate the development of appropriate policies and build an institutional capacity to guide the sector. The component will fund a four-year program of policy and institutional building measures and equipment which will promote the formulation of key physical planning and regulatory instruments, permit the analysis and preparation of policy options, and provide a sequence of capacity- building measures to help the newly forming public and private institutions involved in the housing sector. B. Housing Finance Component to activate commercial mortgage lending to WBG households by assisting commercial banks manage the risks of entering this new business. The component will also initiate the establishment of regulatory and institutional mechanisms to support a sustainable system of mortgage lending, including: (i) A Secondary Mortgage Facility (SMF), to provide liquidity and help lenders manage term intermediation risks by refinancing their long-term mortgage loans, initially with TFGWB funding. The SMF has been established as a private shareholding company. Founding shareholders are the Palestinian Authority and the Palestine Monetary Authority with board representation also from the housing sector. Commercial banks have been invited to become shareholders in the SMF and, together with an experienced technical partner, build the SMF as a commercially viable entity. The IFC is prepared to join as an investor in the capital of the SMF if the transition to sustainable commercial operations can be achieved in a reasonable time. (ii) A Mortgage Indemnity Fund (MIF), to share credit risk with mortgage lenders in WBG. The MIF has been established as a fund initially to be administered by the SMF. Funding for this risk-sharing facility will come from a reserve created from the concessionality of funding provided to the SMF. (iii) A Housing Assistance Fund (HAF) (Funding for this component will be entirely borne by the PA), to provide direct assistance to lower-income home buyers. The HAF will provide subsidies to qualified lower-income households to improve their ability to purchase a dwelling unit. The assistance will help make-up the downpayment for modest-cost housing and 'o lower the loan repayment burden. C. Housing Development Component to help the MOH put in place a mechanism to encourage the production of lower-cost housing by private developers. The MOH/private developer partnership is expected to produce dwelling units estimated to sell for an average of US$25,000 to US$30,000 each, on either: (i) tracts of state land provided with off-site infrastructure on which private developers will bid for the production of qualifying housing
 7 units; and/or (ii) qualifying private lands on which private developers propose and produce qualifying dwellings. In both cases qualifying dwelling units can be either single-family houses or low-rise condominium or cooperative apartment units meeting price ceilings and minimum specifications. This component will help finance: (i) the off-site infrastructure and basic community facilities, initially to a Demonstration Site and to additional sites, as needed in Gaza and West Bank cities, to service tracts of land on which private developers will build and market eligible units; (ii) a Demonstration Site on state-owned land in Gaza City (Tal El-Hawa) for 1,000 units, including infrastructure and facilities, on which developers will design, build and market units; and, (iii) Construction Finance for developers. C. Project Description 2.9 The proposed project establishes and helps build the institutional and financial mechanisms needed for the long-term development of the housing sector. The project will help the MOH implement its policy of having lower-income housing production largely in the hands of private sector developers and financial institutions. 2.10 The Institutional and Policy Development Component. The PA's strategy for improving housing conditions in WBG is to have the public sector adopt an enabling role, while the private sector undertakes the production and financing of housing. The private sector has already demonstrated the engineering and financial capacity to undertake large-scale housing development in the WBG, albeit targeted to the upper-income levels. Commercial banks have considerable liquidity in the form of short- term deposits collected in WBG. They are ready to provide initial lending for housing with the support features included in this project. The public sector institutions, however, are newly established. Housing policy is largely the responsibility of the MOH, which is developing and implementing the regulatory regime necessary for a competitive market-oriented housing system. Under the project, a program of institutional strengthening will be provided to relevant MOH and financial institutions and their service units on: (a) sector planning and regulatory instruments; (b) physical development standards; (c) monitoring and supervision of ongoing projects; (d) procurement planning and contracting (civil works and equipment); (e) training; (f) specialized information and data systems; and (g) coordination and administration of capacity building activities. These capacity building measures will be funded by the project in the form of a structured four-year program to develop policies and norms, and to build the capacity of the financial institutions and the MOH. At negotiations understanding was reached on the program's scope and structure. The first part of the plan will consist of a consultative needs assessment to be carried out as part of the project launch and which will lead to the preparation of a Program Implementation Plan, which will be acceptable to IDA, and finalized no later than July 1, 1997 (para. 7.1). The component includes support for: studies to help introduce institutional reform (staffing, organizational and operational recommendations) proposals; studies and workshops to formulate and deliberate sector policy; on-the-job staff training and specialized training courses; development standards formulation and implementation workshops; advisory services and contracts for developing sector data base information; and providing the MOH with equipment and vehicles needed for maintaining data systems and for implementing the project. Annex 8 describes the program and its elements in greater detail.
 8 2.11 Activating Commercial Mortgage Lending. In order to stimulate and encourage the provision of affordable housing to all employed households and encourage financial sector development in WBG, the project seeks to create a sound and sustainable financial system that features an effective set of institutional mechanisms for providing housing finance. At the core of such a system is the provision of credit by private financial institutions to qualified borrowers. The project envisions the creation of specialized institutions to reallocate a portion of mortgage risk and enhance the affordability of housing. 2.12 The project helps establish the Palestinian Secondary Mortgage Facilitv SMF as a private shareholding company with the purpose of providing long-term finance to banks to reduce the liquidity risk incurred in mortgage lending. A fund to share credit risk with banks making mortgage loans within WBG, termed the Mortgage Indemnity Fund MIF has also been established. Both the provision of long term loans to banks and the sharing of credit risk will facilitate the introduction of mortgage lending in an uncertain economic, legal and regulatory environment. The activities of the SMF and the MIF will increase the flow of funds to housing and improve the affordability of housing finance in WBG. In addition, as the SMF moves to raising funds through the issuance of bonds it may contribute to the development of the local capital market. 2.13 The SMF was registered as a company on March 10, 1997 (Registration # 563122563) with authorized capital of $6 million of which $2 million has been subscribed equally by the PA and the PMA. Private financial institutions have been invited to invest in the SMF and are expected to do so in the near future. The institutional structure within which the SMF will operate is shown below. It will raise funds initially through long-term loans from donors made to the PA who will make these funds available to the SMF for on-lending to qualified' banks in W"G. The terms of the on-lending agreement between the banks and the SMF will include the definition of qualified mortgage loans, standards for bank documentation, loan terms, reporting and underwriting, and the extent of bank provision of mortgage loans from own funds. The SMF will earn a spread between its funding and loan rates. A small portion will be used to cover its administrative costs but most of this spread will be transferred to MIF to be used to share future default losses of the banks. 2.14 The MIF is structured as a fund to share default loses on mortgage. PROJECT SUSTAINABILITY, BENEFITS AND RISKS 6.1 Project Sustainability: The SMF can meet its initial objective of encouraging mortgage lending by a number of commercial banks by refinancing their loans with donor money as proposed. However, the sustainability of the SMF itself is critical if the project is to have a lasting effect on the housing finance system. Once established, the sustainability of the SMF depends upon its ability to raise funds on the domestic and even international markets at some point in the future. At least two rounds of donor support may be necessary to build a proven record and reputation before direct mobilization by the SMF can be achieved. With this in mind the SMF has been established with detailed oversight in respect to its legal structure and governance provisions which will permit and encourage its development as a commercially sustainable institution. The two key events in this transition will be equity investment by private entities and the collaboration with an experienced technical partner. 6.2 Initially the credit risk sharing provision of SMF lending is to be treated as a special loss reserve, created within, but separate from, the SMF's own resources. The pari passu nature of the proposed loss sharing contract with mortgage originators establishes the correct incentives to minimize losses. After some experience it may be possible to set up a Mortgage Insurance Fund on a financially sustainable basis. In the meantime the MIF strategy offers a transparent way to share risks with banks. 6.3 Sustainability of the HAF depends on the fiscal health of the PA. Donor funds are required to maintain this program at present. However, by setting the levels of assistance much lower than previously used in donor housing programs and by requiring considerable financial effort from the household first, the HAF may serve as the model for programs which the PA could eventually finance. As always, the sustainability of the policies and institutions established by a donor-supported project depend on the ownership within the host environment. 6.4 Benefits. The main benefit of the proposed project will be to put in place an institutional and policy framework for the housing sector which will enable housing supply to efficiently respond to the demand for more and better housing and will enhance affordability through the development of a sustainable system of finance combined with directed assistance to poorer families.
 19 6.5 Household borrowers will benefit directly through the ability to access mortgage credit to purchase housing. Lenders will benefit by the provision of long-term loans and through a reduction in their liquidity risk. An increased flow of funds to housing may increase employment in the construction industry and promote stability in the economy. A future benefit of the SMF may be to enhance the development of long-term debt markets. 6.6 Suppliers of housing will primarily benefit from the increased certainty of demand based on the availability of loans to build and purchase new housing. The competitive private sector led process of designing, building and selling the new units will, in an environment of minimal factor price distortions, provide incentives to keep the economic return positive on new housing constructed in conjunction with this project. 6.7 Risks. The project seeks to introduce policies and mechanisms which will encourage a responsive flow of private resources to the housing sector and the production of more, lower-cost dwellings by private developers. The risks associated with a strategy based on voluntary participation by private entities are substantial. They are: (a) those risks associated with developing and implementing sound public sector policies and institutions necessary for the creation of a conducive business environment, (b) the financial and business risks inherent in the highly uncertain economy of the WBG and (c) the technical and institutional risks associated with project specific options selected here. 6.8 Public policy and institutional development is necessarily the core of a project whose objective is longer-term sustainable development of the sector. The particular risks are that concept development, consensus building, decision-making and successful implementation will take longer than expected. There is every possibility that different views and interests will alter progress along the way. The robustness of the project concept based on experience in many countries and the lack of credible alternatives, make this risk worth taking.  Annex 4 Page 1 of 14 WEST BANK AND GAZA HOUSING PROJECT Features of the Housing Development Component The Housing Development Process 1. The project aims at quickly putting in motion a process to test and demonstrate viable options in the special political, institutional and developmental constraints facing Gaza and the West Bank. The Housing Development Component helps the MOH put in place a mechanism that encourages private developers to produce lower-cost housing. The MOH guides the process of housing development on: (i) tracts of State-owned land provided with off-site infrastructure on which private developers will bid for the production of qualifying housing units-either low-rise condominium apartment units or single family houses; (ii) qualifying private lands with apartments and/or single family houses proposed and produced by private developers, (iii) single plots of private land for either single-family houses or low- rise condominium apartments or cooperatives. 2. Because the Housing Project launches the process without the benefit of a full set of tested policies nor with experienced institutions, the project's approach is one of learning-by-doing. The concepts, and options proposed are intended to: (a) quickly respond to the urgent need to provide affordable, appropriate housing to lower- and middle- income households presently without options; and (b) test the options with a view to helping shape policies and capacities to attend to the growing process. 3. The development of land and houses will be done entirely by the private developers. Houses and condominiums will be sold, not leased nor rented, on the basis of installments or final sales, depending on the availability of buyer finance and mortgage collateral. The goal is to have lower cost units and sales prices that reflect full cost recovery. Complementary and parallel to these objectives is that of helping define policies and strategies that will encourage and foster a vigorous housing market. 4. The role of PA Institutions. The Ministry of Housing will supervise the fulfillment of the loan obligations and implement the project on behalf of the PA. The MOH will oversee the operation in terms of consistency with general sector policies. The MOH will guide the process by which developers produce housing units on state or private lands that qualify under the project's financing and assistance programs. To do so the MOH will use a normative instrument called the Developers' Prospectus, in issuing specific calls to developers for proposals to develop specific state lands or to make proposals on developers' own lands (the model document is in Annex 5). 5. Municipalities. will have a supporting role, regulating and approving zoning, construction activities, and in providing maintenance and municipal services to the completed project areas. The Municipal Infrastructure Development Project, FY96 (No. 43339) is providing technical assistance to municipalities to build their capacities to provide this support. 6. The Role of the Developer. The types of private developers operating in Gaza and the West Bank range from very large international firms with the capacity to produce over one thousand apartments per year to small, family-led operations building a few dozen units annually. The bulk of housing construction aimed at the lower end of the housing market is presently covered by the smaller developers (building up to about 100 units, and a very large number of single-site developers building or expanding existing apartments). The project will encourage the participation of all developer types. For this reason the Developers' Prospectus will have editions geared to each site and type of developer.
 Annex 4 Page 2 of 14 7. Development options. Developers are encouraged to test a combination of dwelling types, such as partially finished core dwellings and low-rise condominiums-all ways of reducing the purchase price of a unit, while making it more adaptable to the buyer's preferences. There are considerable differences between Gaza and West Bank cities with respect to land availability, land costs, topography and traditional housing practices/preferences. The program will be flexible in developing options for each locality, based on those considerations, but also intends to demonstrate the viability of housing types and development options. The type of units and condominiums and their proportional distribution will vary, based on local demand and land/ characteristics as determined by the developers. There is a tradition of, strong market preference for, condominium apartments in the Gaza strip. This is linked to land scarcity and cost, as well as to a desire for extended families to live in close proximity. On the other hand, preferences in the West Bank cities are likely to be for single household core units that can be expended and completed over time by the buyer. The distribution of units and types will respond primarily to market forces. 8. The developer will market and sell the units. The developer will propose designs and marketing strategies using the Developers' Prospectus as a guideline. Qualifying design proposals (based on sales price, minimum structural and design characteristics, and responsive to good development practices), will be eligible for buyer financing, the housing assistance fund, etc., making the marketing features more attractive to developers and buyers. The size of core units will be determined by the developer based on a knowledge of market preferences, but apartment buildings will not to exceed 5 stories. Tracts of developed land will likely have a mix of plot/unit types. This will encourage maximizing densities and land values within each site, and increasing the efficient use of scarce land. 9. Role of the purchaser. Households have the option to buy either apartments or single-family units as produced by the private developers. Depending on the type of unit marketed, a buyer may want a unit which an be expanded or completed over time, as household income allows. Individual households purchasing a single-unit plot with basic infrastructure (water, sewerage and storm drainage, and electrical connectors), core dwellings or condominium units which could be partially finished to allow for immediate owner occupancy and completion/expansion in stages, depending on the owner's ability to pay for improvements. Basic partially-finished units adopt more easily to individual needs and preferences. This also provides the option of self-help construction or contracting to small construction firms. 10. Compatibility with on-going programs. Certain elements of the proposed housing component will lend themselves to complement or be logical extensions of on-going donor programs, and could be funded as such. Specific sites and/or components such as community facilities could be earmarked for funding and development of donors on agencies presently active in these areas. Land for Development II. The project envisions the creation of two specialized Housing Finance institutions to provide long-term funds and reallocate a portion of mortgage risk for providers of housing finance in West Bank and Gaza (WBG). The entities are a secondary mortgage facility (SMF) that will provide long term finance to banks and other lenders originating mortgage loans in WBG, and a mortgage indemnity fund (MIF)l that will provide partial default risk insurance for lenders. 2. The SMF will provide liquidity and long-term finance to primary mortgage lenders in order to reduce the liquidity risk incurred in their provision of long term loans for housing. The activities of the SMF will stimulate a flow of funds to housing, improve the affordability of housing finance in WBG and reduce the liquidity risk of the banking sector. 3. The MIF will share potential default loss on residential mortgage loans with lenders in WBG. The MIF should stimulate greater lending for housing in WBG by providing lenders with partial protection against mortgage default loss. The activities of the MIF will stimulate a flow of funds to housing, the development of mortgage credit risk management skills and techniques and in the future allow for a degree of pooling of credit risk among lenders. 4. Household borrowers will benefit through the ability to use mortgage credit to purchase housing and through more favorable terms on mortgage loans. Lenders will benefit through higher portfolio returns and diversification. An increased flow of funds to housing may increase employment in the construction industry and promote stability in the economy. A future benefit of the SMF may be to enhance the development of long term debt markets. Anticipated Benefits of the SMF 5. There is virtually no formal financial sector lending for housing in WBG. Banks operating in the region cite two major reasons for the lack of such lending; the high perceived liquidity risk of extending long term loans in a volatile climate and the high perceived credit risk of extending long term loans in an environment with uncertain property rights and lack of information about or experience with potential mortgage borrowers. 6. The liquidity risk of mortgage lending arises from the fact that in order to be affordable and match the anticipated benefit stream of housing, mortgage loans must be relatively long-term (e.g., 15 or more years). The banks currently fund themselves with a mix of short-term deposits (approximately 95%) and equity (approximately 5%). They are reluctant to provide mortgage loans funded with deposits because they perceive a significant risk that instability in WBG could lead to a substantial outflow of deposits. If a substantial portion of their assets are in the form of long-term loans, they may have insufficient funds available to meet depositors' demands. Although shareholder equity is a longer-term source of funds, the banks are unwilling to invest such funds in an activity that they believe offer a low risk-adjusted rate of return. I/ Initially the MIF will be introduced as a separate account within the SMF.

If a bank uses SMF loans to finance a portion of its mortgage portfolio, it can achieve a duration match between its mortgage assets and liabilities. Furthermore, if the SMF is perceived to be a source of liquidity (i.e., a lender of first resort) the banks may be more likely to extend mortgage loans funded by deposits. Banks offering mortgage loans may be able to earn a higher risk-adjusted rate of return on their asset portfolios (i.e., arising from switching from other assets to mortgage loans) and provide a more compete range of services to their customers.2 8. The benefits for household borrowers arise from the availability of mortgage loans. The value to consumers currently depends on their ability and willingness to borrow for the purchase of a home. As there is no mortgage lending in WBG, it is impossible to formulate the willingness to pay for home mortgage loans. For some households, the benefit will be the substitution of lower cost debt for equity finance. However, we have no information on the investment choices or returns on Palestinian households. For other households with no savings, the value of the loans will be in the form of access to higher quality housing. Presumably this could be measured by the difference in the housing consumption before and after receiving the loan. This is also very difficult to measure as many households share space and expenditure with extended family members. Over time, as more lenders enter the market, borrowers should also benefit from competition among lenders in the form of more favorable mortgage loan terms (lower cost of funds and a longer term on loans being offered). 9. In addition to the benefits for lenders and households, there are also potentially significant external benefits generated by the SMF. An increase in housing demand spurred by mortgage lending can lead to expanded employment in the construction industry. This benefit may be substantial given the high rates of unemployment in WBG. Developing a private sector housing finance system will take the pressure off the PA to develop its own sources of housing finance, resulting in a greater ability to focus scarce subsidy resources on lower income households. A steady supply of mortgage finance could lead to increased stability in WBG if housing overcrowding is reduced. Finally, the SMF could be a catalyst for bond market development in the future. 10. Lenders in WBG also view mortgage lending as a business with potentially high credit risk. There are several reasons for this perception. Second, the legal system supporting mortgage lending is untested. Although the legal basis for property ownership, mortgage and foreclosure exists, the property registries are incomplete (many transactions are not consummated with a definitive transfer of title) and the ability of the court system to have claims enforced against owners is unknown. A third factor is the political instability in the area. Both the West Bank and Gaza are subject to frequent border closings that disrupt the income earning ability of residents. 11. The high perceived level of credit risk is at least a strong deterrent to mortgage lending as the high perceived level of liquidity risk. Thus, term loans from the SMF are currently perceived as insufficient to stimulate mortgage lending in WBG. The relocation of any graves will be done in consultation with religious authorities and the Resident Mission. Specific information on the required review procedures is provided Paras. 13-19 (below). 13. Consultation with Physical Planning Department. Consultations will be conducted with the Physical Planning Department of the Ministry of Planning and International Cooperation to assure the proposed actions are consistent with the principles of the Physical Master Plans for the West Bank and Gaza Strip and special physical master plans which are being developed for Jericho, Ramallah and Gaza City among others. The findings of this consultation will be provided as an element of the approval package for the proposed activity. 14. Consultation with Municipality. Consultations will be conducted with the Planning Department and Infrastructure Departments of the concerned Municipal Government. These consultations will include review and formal clearance of the proposed site with regard to zoning. The consultation will also include a review of current and required access to municipal infrastructure services including water supply, sewage systems, solid waste collection and storm water management. The municipality, MOH and private sector developer will be required to reach an agreement on the services to be provided, which parties will be responsible for their funding and installation, and the timing of the installation of these services. The findings of this consultation will be provided as an element of the approval package for the proposed activity. 15. Environmental Review and Clearance. The Environmental Planning Directorate of the Ministry of Planning and Intemational Cooperation should be contacted and requested to conduct an environmental review of proposed Project activities to be undertaken to assure they are consistent with current Palestinian requirements. The preparation of these reviews may require a field visit by representatives of the Environmental Planning Directorate to the concerned sites. It is requested that a formal record of these reviews concerning the acceptability of the proposed activities be obtained from the Environmental Planning Directorate and made part of the review process and project record. 16. Archaeological Review and Clearance. The Palestinian Department of Archaeology of the Ministry of Tourism and Antiquities will be contacted and requested to conduct an archaeological and historical sites review at each site proposed for support under the HDC. It should be anticipated that this will require a preliminary field survey to be conducted by archaeologists acceptable to the Palestinian Department of Archaeology. A formal record of these reviews concerning the acceptability of the proposed activities be obtained from the Palestinian Department of Archaeology. In addition, all contractors retained by the MOH and private sector developers will be required to used "archaeological chance find procedures" given the potential for unknown archaeological materials to be uncovered at sites in the West Bank and Gaza. 17. Historical Buildings Review and Clearance. The Ministry of Culture will be contacted and requested to conduct an on site review of any proposed activity under the HDC involving the modification and/or demolition of any historic buildings over 50 year old. A formal record of these reviews conceming the acceptability of the proposed activities be obtained from the Ministry of Culture.
 Annex 14 Page 6 of 12 18. Relocation of Graves. Religious authorities and the relatives of the buried persons will be formally consulted prior to the relocation of any graves. A formal record of these consultations and the decision of the religious authorities will be provided to the MOH and Resident Mission for review and approval prior to the relocation of graves. Design measures will be used to the fullest extent possible to avoid the relocation of graves under the HDC. 19. Resettlement, Land Acquisition and Compensation Issues. The evolving status of the Palestinian administrative procedures and determination of lines of authority, including operational differences between West Bank and Gaza, requires that proposed activities under the HDC be reviewed for resettlement aspects by the MOH on an individual basis, with the close supervision of the Resident Mission and support of EMTEN. This will involve site specific reviews and preparation of proposed compensation packages which will require Bank review and approval. A condition of the loan will be that the Palestinian Authority, acting through the MOH, will agree to use the following review process for activities to be supported under the Housing Development Component of the proposed Project: a. Legal Status of the Proposed Site. Information will be provided on the official land ownership status of each proposed site. This review will identify any outstanding claims or disputes concerning title to all or any portion of the site. b. Survey of Current Land Use on the Site. A map should be prepared for each site which shows the current land use, including both authorized and unauthorized activities. This will identify areas which are being used for informal housing or have structures, locations of agricultural activities, sand or rock excavation, waste disposal sites, and other uses. c. Identification of Formal and Informal Users. A list will be made, keyed to the map, which will identify to the fullest extent possible the names of the formal and informal users and provide information on the basis for their land use activities on the sites. To the extent they are available, information or copies of leases or other authorizations for agriculture or other activities will be collected. Under the provisions of World Bank/IDA resettlement procedures, compensation may be required for parties with informal rights as well as for those with formal rights. d. Consultation with Formal and Informal Users. In the development of sites larger than 20 dunums in area, the MOH will organize a public consultation process with formal and informal users of the proposed site. This consultation will include a review of the proposed activity, the rights of the affected parties, and the procedures to be used for compensation. The process will provide for an opportunity for potentially affected parties to express their views and preferences with regard to compensation. A record will be made of these consultations by MOH which will be maintained in the Project files and provided to the Resident Mission. e. Estimation of Potential Compensation for Formal and Informal Users. Preliminary information should be prepared concerning proposed costs of compensation for parties with either formal or informal land use rights. A review will be prepared which will provide information on the value and replacement costs of structures, outbuildings, fences, vines, trees and other non-moveable assets. Preference will be given to the provision of altemate housing for parties subject to involuntary resettlement and all compensation will be based on real market rates which reflect real market value and replacement costs.
 Annex 14 Page 7 of 12 f. Review of Proposed Compensation and Payment. Given the wide variations in costs between the different sections of the West Bank and Gaza, determinations for all proposed compensation packages, including the provision of alternative housing, will be made on a case-by-case basis in consultation with the MOH, municipal government, and affected parties. In addition, the payments will be made in a transparent and public manner in which the affected parties receive payment in a public location with a public notice being given of the compensation and the individual who received the award. All proposed compensation activities will be formally reviewed and approved by the Resident Mission with the support of EMTEN as required. 20. Review of Proposed Demonstration Site in Gaza. A review of environment, cultural heritage and resettlement issues at the proposed Tal al Hawa demonstration site in Gaza is provided as Attachment A. This site has been subject to a field survey by representatives of MOH and IDA which has confirmed that it does have any known formal or informal housing which would require involuntary resettlement. Development of Palestinian Resettlement Procedures 21. Under the Institutional and Policy Development Component of the Project support will be provided for the development of procedures for use by the MOH for involuntary resettlement and land acquisition. The development of these procedures be undertaken in coordination with development of laws and regulations by the recently elected Palestinian Assembly. This process will be complemented by Project supported training courses concerning environment, cultural heritage and resettlement issues. Institutional Strengthening 22. In order to support effective implementation of the Project, as an element of the Institutional and Policy Development Component, a series of short training courses on environment, cultural heritage, and resettlement issues related to the HDC will be conducted for public and private interests in cooperation with EPD, PDA and MOC. These courses will be conducted in Arabic and make use of the recently completed translations of relevant Operational Directives, the Environmental Assessment Sourcebook (3 volumes) and selected updates to the Sourcebook, including procedures concerning cultural heritage. Additional materials will be prepared in Arabic concerning resettlement and land acquisition issues. Monitoring and Supervision 23. Monitoring of the implementation of environment, cultural heritage and resettlement aspects of the Project will be conducted by the MOH with the support of the Resident Mission. These issues will be elements of the routine supervision missions to be conducted for the Project and IDA staff andlor consultants with expertise in environment and resettlement issues will participate as members of the supervision missions. EMTEN will provide specialized support to the Resident Mission, as required, in undertaking monitoring and supervision activities. Agreements 24. Project Agreements. It is recommended that the Project include the following agreements between the MOH and IDA:
 Annex 14 Page 8 of 12 a. Assurances will be provided by the MOH, that both public and private sector organizations implementing the Housing Development Component will obtain formal clearances for Project supported construction activities from the Environmental Planning Department of the Ministry of Planning and International Cooperation and the Palestinian Department of Archaeology of the Ministry of Tourism and Antiquities. In the case of proposed activities which concern the modification and/or demolition of historical buildings, more than 50 years old, formal clearances will be obtained from the Ministry of Culture. While the relocation of graves will require formal approval by religious authorities. b. Assurances will be provided by the MOH, that both public and private sector organizations implementing the Housing Development Component will follow the provisions of World Bank Operational Directive 4.30, "Involuntary Resettlement" in cases when Project supported activities may involve the resettlement of parties with either formal or informal land rights, including the agricultural use of lands. The World Bank/IDA will be formally consulted conceming all proposed Project funded activities which may involve involuntary resettlement or the relocation of graves. c. Assurances will be provided by the MOH, that it will prepare as an element of the Project a set of procedures for involuntary resettlement which could be implemented by the Palestinian Authority for this and other projects. Coordination with Ongoing Activities 25. Implementation of the Project will be coordinated with, but not limited to, the following on-going activities: a. Physical Planning Study. The Ministry of Planning and International Cooperation is preparing a physical planning study for the West Bank and Gaza, including special studies for Jericho, Ramallah and Gaza City, with support from the Government of Norway; b. Tourism Development Program. The Ministry of Tourism and Antiquities plans to undertake preparation of a tourism development program from the West Bank and Gaza. This activity is to be supported under the Technical Assistance Trust Fund (TATF); c. Cultural Resources Management Plan. The Ministry of Tourism and Antiquities, in coordination with the Ministry of Culture, plans to undertake preparation of a cultural resources management program for the West Bank and Gaza. This activity is to be supported under the TATF; d. Gaza and West Bank Environmental Profle Process. The Environmental Planning Directorate of the Ministry of Planning and International Cooperation is preparing an Environmental Profile for Gaza with support from the Government of the Netherlands. In addition, an Environmental Profile for the West Bank is planned to be prepared by EPD with donor assistance; e. Coastal Zone Management Program. The Environmental Planning Directorate of the Ministry of Planning and International Coordination plans to undertake preparation of a
 Annex 14 Page 9 of 12 coastal zone management program for Gaza. This activity is to be supported under the TATF; and f. Bethlehem and Jericho Environmental Profiles. The Applied Research Institute in Jerusalem (ARIJ) has prepared an Environmental Profile for Bethlehem and has an Environmental Profile of Jericho under preparation.
 Annex 14 Page 10 of 12 Attachment A WEST BANK AND GAZA HOUSING PROJECT Housing Development Component Tal El-Hawa Demonstration Site Environment, Cultural Heritage And Resettlement Review Overview 1. Introduction. Under the Housing Development Component (HDC) of the Palestinian Housing Project (Project) it is proposed to implement a demonstration activity at Tal El-Hawa in Gaza Municipality. Consistent with procedures adopted by the Ministry of Housing (MOH) of the Palestinian Authority and the International Development Association (IDA) this site has been the subject of field based reviews of environment, cultural heritage and resettlement issues. 2. Field Survey. To support the review process a field survey was conducted of the sites by representatives of the MOH and IDA (MN2WG, TWURD, ENVLW). This inspection covered the entire area of the site by the team which was assisted by the chief surveyor for Gaza. The inspection of the site was done on foot, local residents were consulted and sketch maps were prepared of the site. The survey confirmed that the proposed site does not have any known formal or informal housing which would require involuntary relocation. 3. At the request of IDA, the MOH is having detailed maps prepared of the location which will show current land use and identify the parties involved. The project team is working with the MOH and the concerned municipal governments to develop proposed compensation measures for parties which are engaged in agriculture on a formal and informnal basis. The proposed compensation packages and their method of payment will be subject to review and approval by the Resident Mission and EMTEN as a condition for negotiation of the Trust Fund Credit Agreement and payments will be made to affected parties prior to undertaking the demonstration activity. 4. Review by Palestinian Agencies. The demonstration site has been subject to field visits by representatives of the Environmental Planning Directorate of the Ministry of Planning and International Cooperation and the Palestinian Department of Archaeology of the Ministry of Tourism and Antiquities. Both these organizations have provided formal clearances for the proposed demonstration activity. No site visits were required by representatives of the Ministry of Culture since the proposed activities did not involve any historic structures. Tal El-Hawa Demonstration Site 5. Tal El-Hawa. The Tal El-Hawa site is located in the southern part of Gaza Municipality and covers and area of 406 dunums. The field review indicates that the area is suitable for development for housing under the HDC. The site is surrounded on all four sides by existing housing and is bordered by three sides by large roads which provide adequate access to the site. Current land use at the site includes areas which are used, under both formal leases with the municipality and under informal use rights established during the Israeli occupation, for the cultivation vegetables, vines and trees. A portion of the site is covered with
 Annex 14 Page 11 of 12 trees, brush and other vegetation. Several sections of the site are being illegally excavated for sand and used as solid waste disposal sites. The site does not have any housing units which will be subject to voluntary or involuntary resettlement. 6. Potential Impacts. The potential impacts from implementation of the proposed activity are limited in their scope and can be addressed through implementation of mitigation actions and monitoring. The primary impacts include: a. Conversion of Open Area. The site will be converted from an open area into a housing development which will include planned public and family use areas. Trees, brush and other types of vegetation will be removed from most of the site and the topography of the site will be altered to allow for development of the land and to assure proper stormwater drainage. The change in land use will be irreversible. b. Loss of Areafor Cultivation. The site will cease to be used for the low intensity cultivation of vegetables, vines and fruit trees. The site is composed of mobile sand and does not possess valuable soil types which should be conserved for agricultural production. c. Control of Unauthorized Sand Excavation and Waste Disposal. A major positive benefit of the proposed activity will be the ending of extensive unauthorized excavation of sand from two extensive pits which have been illegally established on the site. These are up to 15 meters deep and create a hazard for local residents and result in seasonal ponding of water resulting in the creation of breeding habitat for mosquitoes. It will also result in the ending of the use of the site for waste disposal purposes by a wide range of unauthorized parties. 7. Mitigation Actions. Proposed mitigation actions for this activity are: a. Conservation of Acacia Trees. Field review of the site by the Environmental Planning Directorate resulted in a formal request that the design for the site include provision for the protection of an area of acacia trees located in the central and eastern portion of the site. The MOH has agreed to this proposal and adopted it as a mitigation for development of the site. b. Compensationfor Agricultural Users. A compensation package, acceptable to IDA, should be provided to those parties which have established formal and informal land use rights at the site and have established trees and grapevines on portions of the site. The compensation package should be developed following the procedures outlined in the next steps section in Para. 9 (below). c. Use ofArchaeological Chance Find Procedures. The MOH will require its contractors and private sector developers to use "archaeological chance find procedures" given the potential for unknown archaeological materials to be uncovered at this site during the excavation and construction process. 8. Monitoring Actions. Implementation of the proposed activity will be monitored by the MOH and Resident Mission. Both parties will assure that no construction activities will be undertaken until the activities outlined in Para. 9 (below) are completed.

Prior to approval of the proposed activity the following actions should be taken by the MOH to resolve the compensation of parties which have formal and informal land use rights at the site as follows: a. Complete Review of the Legal Status of the Site. The MOH should complete the review of official land ownership status of each proposed site. This review will identify any outstanding claims or disputes concerning title to all or any portion of the site. b. Complete the Survey of Current Land Use on the Site. A map should be prepared for each site which shows the current land use, including both authorized and unauthorized activities. c. Complete the Identifcation of Formal and Informal Users. A list should be made prepared which will be keyed to the map which will identify to the fullest extent possible the names of the formal and informal users and provide information on the basis for their land use activities on the sites. To the extent they are available information or copies of leases or other authorizations for agriculture or other activities should be collected. d. Conduct a Consultation with Formal and Informal Users. The MOH should organize a public consultation process with formal and informal users of the proposed site. This consultation will include a review of the proposed activity, the rights of the affected parties, and the procedures to be used for compensation. The process will provide for an opportunity for potentially affected parties to express their views and preferences with regard to compensation. e. Prepare an Estimate of Potential Compensation for Formal and Informal Users. Preliminary information should be prepared concerning proposed costs of compensation for parties with either formal or informal land use rights. All compensation will be based on real market rates which reflect real market value and replacement costs. f. Payment of Compensation. The MOH, in consultation with the municipal government and affected parties, will prepare a proposal for payment of compensation which will be formally reviewed and approved by the Resident Mission with the support of EMTEN as required. Following IDA approval the MOH will make payments and the site will be available for development under the HDC.

doc.abstracts: The housing project seeks to demonstrate that appropriate, lower cost housing options can be achieved and that financing can be made available on a sustainable basis. The specific objectives of the project are to: a) put in place institutions, policies and actions necessary to building and sustain a well-functioning housing sector; b) make housing more affordable by initiating the development of a competitive, market-based mortgage system, accompanied by well-targeted assistance to lower -income households; and c) reduce house prices for lower income households by reducing obstacles to the availability of land; promoting a competitive development process for lower cost alternatives; and providing assistance for the capital costs of infrastructure. The three project components are: a) institutional and policy development component; b) housing finance component, including, a secondary mortgage facility, a mortgage indemnity fund, and a housing assistance fund; c) housing development component which will help finance the off-site infrastructure and basic community facilities, a demonstration site, and construction finance.
